section.hand:
To my L. Treasuro
r
Sep
t
27. 89.

page.lettertext:
fol.127r
Belgia 1589 27 Septem
b
To
e Lord Treasror From M
r
Bodly
Right hono
r
& my singul
r
good Lord, to
e purpose of
t mothion,
in the behalf of
Count Maurice
, wh
r
of I signifyed in my last
to yo
r
L. there hath nothing bin im
ted to mee. his late
s
vices have
much augmented his credit, & yt is a gen
r
all opinion
t he will
prove very valliant & wyse wh
r
of he giveth in all his actions very
manifest tokens. the
Generall states
have concluded & have delt
to that effect w
th
e
Counsell of state
that from this tyme forward,
in the su
scription of theyr letters & oth
r
writing
they will give him the
title of
Hooghe gheboren voorst
in lieu of
Hoogh & wellgheboren
Graeff w
ch
is high boren prince in place of highe & welboren Count
w
ch
was his title heertofore. & in the Context of theyr writing for
uwer liefden
, yo
r
lovingnes they will use heeraffter
Uwe
Furslichte genaede
yo
r
princely grace or els
uwe Ex
cie
yo
r
excellen
cy
nev
r
theles they have bestowed no actuall dignity uppon him w
ch
makes
many men to muse at this Hyster
o
Proter
o
. The Count doth
continew very carefully his good usage of
S
r
Francis vere
& the
other English Captayns & souldiers & I may not omyt to adv
r
tyse
yo
r
L. that S
r
Francis Vere by meanes of his valle
r
& good
gov
r
ment hath won great reputation not onely w
th
the Count but
also w
th
e common Capteynes & souldiers of both nations, &
wheth
r
in
cesse of tyme yt be not likely to prove that conducto
rs
heer of meaner calling then such as heertofore have bin sent by
her
Ma
ty
will bett
r
fytt wth
e humo
r
of this people I leave
be consydered by yo
r
L. The good discipline & sufficiency
of those English Captayenes that have
s
ved about
Bommel
hath bin highly comendyed by
e Count & by others & in a
gen
r
all assembly of the States & Counsell of State hath bin
publickly declared how much the Country hath bin steeded that
summer by hir Ma
tyes
forces. It hath bin also signifyed
to
e State by Count Maurice,
Count William
, &
Count
Hohenloo
, that they do not fynde in all
e Provinces all
[accounted]
t may conveniently be drawen into
s
vice above
800 footem
e
& 600 horse besides those of hir Ma
ties
assistance
wh
r
uppon there hath bin a gen
r
all conference to sett a bett
r
order for keeping theyr Companies Complete & for the establishment
of theyr whole state of warres, w
ch
wh
e
yt is
fitted I will
send to yo
r
L. Count William hath recommended unto th
e
an
offer made by his father
Count John
, who
miseth that for
a small pension to be distributed among such
sons, as he
will specify unto th
e
being gentlemen of his owne contrey about
Dillembourgh
they shalbe
s
ved wth 4 regiment
of footem
e
& 4 companies of horse [accounting] to every regitment of foote
3000 & to each companye of horse 1000 for w
ch
they are to
disbourse yerely for a regiment of footemen 1500 rickes dollers
& for 1000 horse 1000 dallers & they wilbe alwayes
[in a]
fol.127v
redynes to be employed in any
s
vice of
e Contrey up
o
very
short warning. Wheth
r
they will accept of
e offer yt is not
yet knowen, but they seeme at this p
nt
to herken
willingly unto yt. & they have written to
e Provinces to
know theyr liking. Of
e Enemyes proceding that is
still c
o
fyrmed w
ch
I adv
r
tysed in my last to
M
r
Secretary
t he hath left
e siege of
Huesden
. some say th
r
uppon that
his footm
e
are gon toward
Liege
. & toward
Luxembourg
but 10 cornet
of horse toward
Berck
. W
ch
hath caused
th
e
heere to deale very earnestly w
th
S
r
Francis Vere to go
w
th
Count Newenar
for
e reliefe of
e Towne, w
ch
is accorded
&
ei meet in
Geldreland
w
th
in these 2 dayes the Count w
th
600 horse & as many foote. S
r
Francis wth 900 footemen
&
e horse Company of
S
r
Nicholas Parker
wee have also
intelligence
t some
t of the Enemyes troupes are gon
towarde
Friseland
. Of any passed into
Fraunce
we have
no c
r
tayn adv
r
tisement. yt is rath
r
gen
r
ally thought
t
e forces sent
t waye continew as yet uppon
e fronteers
expecting some aunswer from those of
e League. the
Deputyes from hence
t are to be sent in a Gratulatory
Embassadge to
e
F
r
Kinge
are in redines to de
t to wytt
Lodovic Brederode
a young
r
broth
r
of
e famely
Sylla
e
pensioner of Amsterdame &
La Pre
there last ag
e
t in France
there goeth also in company as from Count Maurice
Justinus
his
brother. Astouching
e fortific
ao
ns of
Oostend
to such effect
as
S
r
John Conway
had written to yo
r
L. & I was willed by
my
LL. of
e Counsell
to move
e states I have delt a great
while synce but c
a
have no oth
r
aunswer as yet but
t they
will consider uppon yt
& thus beseeching yo
r
L. to im
te these
ticulars w
th
M
r
Secretary I take my humble leave.
Hage
26 Sept
e
b
r
89.
